## GAD-7 vs EAS

GAD-7 vs EAS: Enhanced Harmonization for Psychologists In the world of psychology research, questionnaire harmonisation is a crucial aspect, especially when one is seeking to compare or correlate distinct psychological assessments. Such is the case when comparing GAD-7 vs EAS - two popular instruments often used in mental health research. The GAD-7 (Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment) and the EAS (Emotionality Activity Sociability Temperament Survey for Children) have different sets of items assessing different domains. A tool like Harmony becomes instrumental in making these comparisons seamlessly. Harmony leverages advanced natural language processing algorithms and generative AI to harmonise and compare the items in GAD-7 vs EAS with remarkable precision and efficiency. By using Harmony’s user-friendly web interface, psychologists can select the two instruments from Harmony’s extensive database or upload their own PDFs directly into the system. Harmony makes it possible to compare the items between GAD-7 vs EAS in multiple languages and provides a percentage match between each corresponding item. With Harmony, researchers can save precious time and devote their resources to the analysis and interpretation of their findings, thus, elevating the quality of their work.

## Compare the items in GAD-7 English and EAS

* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import GAD-7 and EAS into Harmony and harmonise them</a> - find similarities between the two instruments using our AI platform
* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just GAD-7 into Harmony</a> - compare GAD-7 English with other instruments
* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just EAS into Harmony</a> - compare EAS with other instruments


## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
